I applaud the Biden Administration in their continued efforts to fight #COVID19 and the critical steps the President is taking to keep communities across the nation safe.

The #BipartisanInfrastructureLaw is a win-win for all, and I am committed to working with local stakeholders to ensure that our community receives its fair share of resources and every city can successfully draw down the funds available to meet their infrastructure priorities.
In total, these infrastructure investments will improve the quality of life in our communities, while creating good-paying jobs, boosting our economy, and addressing the climate crisis.
These investments will drive demand for zero-emission, cleaner vehicles and makes our country go more greener than ever.

To address air pollution that disproportionately impacts our most vulnerable communities, the law invests $7.5 billion in clean school buses and ferries and $7.5 billion for electric vehicle charging infrastructure.

The law also delivers clean and safe drinking water to families across the country and invests $55 billion in water infrastructure, including over $23 billion for drinking and wastewater infrastructure and $15 billion for the replacement of lead pipes.

The #BipartisanInfrastructureLaw ensures every American has access to reliable and affordable high-speed internet. The new law invests $65 billion in broadband infrastructure, which is all the more critical especially now during the pandemic.

Funding highlights include:
$110B for roads and bridges
$66B for passenger and freight rail
$11B for highway and pedestrian safety
$39B for transit systems, incl. increasing accessibility for seniors and people with disabilities
$17B for our ports and harbors
and so much more!

This historic legislation will be crucial to growing our local and national economies and helping our communities plan their growth, connect our cities, and significantly improve safety along our roads, bridges, public transit, and rail systems.
Recently, I hosted a roundtable with mayors and city leaders from across the region to discuss the transformative investments of the #BipartisanInfrastructureLaw. https://t.co/NO2ytBbaEs

The #WomenVetsTaskForce honors Staff Sergeant Julia Kabance for her remarkable contributions and distinguished service to our country. https://t.co/nINRp2T0C6

For her years of distinguished service to our nation, she received the Good Conduct Medal, the World War II Victory Medal, the American Campaign Medal, and the DAR Distinguished Citizen Medal. https://t.co/kmNJ5Rvl8u
After retiring in 1972, Kabance moved to St. Mary‚Äôs, Kansas, where she spent her time volunteering for her church and was an active and proud member of the American Legion We-Ta-Se Post 410.
She also volunteered at the VA Medical Center in Topeka for over 17 years serving her fellow veterans. https://t.co/PK071hVacB

Following her service, she moved home to care for her ailing mother. She was then employed by the U.S. Air Force in Topeka, Kansas and she later worked in accounting for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. https://t.co/TqPzm4SATw

During World War II, Kabance was stationed at McChord Air Force Base and Fort Leavenworth, where she provided administrative support and spent time as a driver for the U.S. Army. After the war, due to the loss of her hearing, Kabance was honorably discharged as a staff sergeant.
Julia attended basic training at Fort Des Moines Cavalry Post, where she stayed in barracks that had been converted from horse stables.
Julia attended Kewanka grade school and Holton High School, then Haskell Indian Nations University for a year before enlisting in the Women‚Äôs Army Auxiliary Corps in 1943. https://t.co/ioj44W2xVS

As we continue the #WomensVetsTaskForce series celebrating the contributions of #womenvets, we commemorate the life and service of Julia Kabance, who was the oldest World War II woman veteran and member of the Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation when she passed on November 16, 2021. https://t.co/nltU2pzZjv
